Literature Review: The human microbiome, particularly the gut microbiota, plays a pivotal role in maintaining immune homeostasis and modulating inflammation. In the context of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, despite the success of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in suppressing viral replication, people living with HIV (PLWH) continue to experience chronic inflammation and immune dysfunction. This persistent immune dysregulation is a significant barrier to achieving a functional cure for HIV, as it contributes to the maintenance of latent viral reservoirs and the prevalence of clinical comorbidities. Recent research has begun to unravel the complex interplay between the microbiome, microbial metabolites, and immune responses in PLWH, offering new insights into potential therapeutic targets. Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and bile acids (BAs), two families of metabolites produced or modified by gut bacteria, have emerged as key players in this interaction. SCFAs, including acetate, propionate, and butyrate, are known to exert anti-inflammatory effects and regulate the function of various immune cells. BAs, on the other hand, have been shown to modulate immune responses through interactions with host receptors such as the farnesoid X receptor (FXR) and the G protein-coupled bile acid receptor 1 (GPBAR1). The dysregulation of SCFA and BA production, often a consequence of gut dysbiosis, has been implicated in the chronic inflammation and immune dysfunction observed in PLWH. Studies have demonstrated that alterations in the gut microbiome of PLWH are associated with reduced levels of SCFAs and altered BA profiles, which in turn may contribute to the persistence of latent HIV by promoting a pro-inflammatory environment and impairing immune surveillance. Furthermore, SCFAs and BAs have been shown to influence the differentiation and function of T cells, including regulatory T cells (Tregs) and T helper 17 (Th17) cells, which play critical roles in maintaining immune balance and controlling viral replication. The manipulation of SCFA and BA levels, either through dietary interventions, probiotics, or pharmacological agents, represents a promising strategy for restoring immune homeostasis and reducing HIV persistence. However, the precise mechanisms by which SCFAs and BAs modulate immune responses in the context of HIV infection remain to be fully elucidated. Future research should focus on delineating the cellular and molecular pathways through which these metabolites influence immune function and HIV latency, as well as exploring the therapeutic potential of targeting the microbiome and its metabolites in PLWH. By advancing our understanding of the role of the microbiome and microbial metabolites in HIV pathogenesis, we can pave the way for novel interventions aimed at achieving a functional cure for HIV.
